claim: Recombinant technology leads to a broader immune response that may provide cross-protection, even in a mismatch season.
explanation: Four‐panel figure showing serologic comparisons among four influenza vaccines (Fluzone IIV4, Fluarix IIV4, ccIIV4, RIV4) in two age groups (18–44 years in panels A and C, 45–64 years in panels B and D). Panels A and B plot the geometric mean ratio of egg‐grown to cell‐grown virus titers one month post‐vaccination with 95% confidence intervals, with horizontal bars indicating statistically significant differences. Panels C and D show the proportion of participants with a ≥4‐fold reduction in titer to cell‐grown virus from pre‐ to one month post‐vaccination, with p‐values for changes in each vaccine group. RIV4 consistently has the lowest egg/cell ratio and shows a significant drop in the proportion with reduced cell‐virus titers. Evidence: RIV4 group exhibits significantly lower geometric mean egg/cell titer ratios for A(H3N2) compared to egg‐based vaccines and a significant reduction in the proportion of participants with ≥4‐fold reduced titer to cell vaccine virus (e.g., 58% pre vs. 26% post in 18–44 years, p=0.0001). The data show that the recombinant vaccine (RIV4) elicits antibodies with less bias toward egg-grown epitopes and greater reactivity to cell-grown virus, consistent with broader immune responses; this supports the claim Note: These are serologic surrogate endpoints rather than direct measures of clinical cross-protection in a mismatch season; interpretation is limited to immune‐response markers
